qas.question: Why is Warsaw's flora very rich in species?
What is the Bielany Forest the last remnant of?
What forest is by Warsaw's southern border?
How many botanical gardens does Warsaw have?
How many botanical gardens does Kampinos have?
Why is Kampinos's flora very rich in species?
What is the Kampinos Forest the last remnant of?
What forest is by Kampinos's southern border?

context: The flora of the city may be considered very rich in species. The species richness is mainly due to the <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b6_0><b7_0>location<a0_2/> of Warsaw<b7_0/><b6_0/><a0_1/><a0_0/> within the border region of several big floral regions comprising substantial proportions of close-to-wilderness areas (natural forests, wetlands along the Vistula) as well as arable land, meadows and forests. Bielany Forest, located <a1_0><a1_2>within the borders of <a1_1>Warsaw<a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>, is the remaining part of the <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b8_0>Masovian Primeval Forest<b8_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>. Bielany Forest nature reserve is connected with Kampinos Forest. It is home to rich fauna and flora. Within the forest there are three cycling and walking trails. Other big forest area is <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b9_0>Kabaty<b9_0/><a3_2/><a3_0/> Forest<a3_1/> by the southern city border. Warsaw has also <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2><b5_0>two<b5_0/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/> botanic gardens: by the Łazienki park (a didactic-research unit of the University of Warsaw) as well as by the Park of Culture and Rest in Powsin (a unit of the Polish Academy of Science).
